item.title: Frame Cashless Treatment Scheme For Road Accident Victims During 'Golden Hour' By March 14 : Supreme Court Directs Centre - Live Law - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Supreme Court Directs Cashless Treatment Scheme for Accident Victims by March 14, 2025

Date: January 8, 2025 | Source: LiveLaw

The Supreme Court of India has mandated the Central Government to create a scheme for cashless treatment for motor vehicle accident victims within the critical first hour of injury, referred to as the 'golden hour', by March 14, 2025. This initiative aims to save lives by ensuring immediate medical care.

  • The Court emphasized the urgency in implementing the scheme which has been a statutory obligation since the Motor Vehicles Act was updated.
  • Concerns were raised about existing delays in medical treatment due to payment issues and police delays.
  • Section 162 of the Motor Vehicles Act mandates a cashless treatment scheme, yet no scheme has been established despite this legal requirement.
  • Issues surrounding the draft concept note submitted by the Central Government were highlighted, particularly limitations on treatment amounts and coverage duration.
  • The Court ordered the creation of a Motor Vehicle Accident Fund to provide financial support for treatment costs.
“Once the scheme is framed and its implementation starts, it will save the lives of several injured persons...” - Supreme Court

Additionally, the Court reviewed the hit-and-run compensation scheme and noted the low claim rates despite the frequency of such accidents. They have directed improvements to expedite claims processing.

The Court's order aims to solidify the legal framework surrounding accident victim treatment and compensation, enhancing road safety and emergency care in India.

item.title: Passing comments on woman's "body structure" is sexual harassment: Kerala High Court - Bar & Bench - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Kerala High Court Rules Comments on Women's Body Structure Constitute Sexual Harassment

Date: 08 Jan 2025

Source: Kerala High Court

The Kerala High Court recently declared that comments regarding a woman's 'body structure' can be considered sexual harassment, emphasizing the importance of protecting women's modesty.

  • The case involved remarks made by a man about a woman's body, which the court found to be inappropriate.
  • Justice A Badharudeen noted that such comments prima facie constitute sexual harassment under Sections 354A and 509 of the Indian Penal Code.
  • The court dismissed the accused's appeal to quash the proceedings against him, agreeing that the behaviour indicated a pattern of harassment.
“In the instant case the allegation of the prosecution is that the accused with intention to outrage the modesty of the defacto complainant...commented that the body structure of the defacto complainant was fine...”

The court's ruling highlights the judicial stance against sexual harassment and reinforces the notion that comments on a woman’s body can have serious legal implications.

item.title: Is organizing protests sufficient to invoke UAPA? Delhi High Court asks police in Delhi riots case - Bar & Bench - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Delhi High Court Questions Validity of UAPA in Protests Against CAA

Published on: 08 Jan 2025, 11:54 am

The Delhi High Court is deliberating whether setting up protest sites against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act is sufficient for the police to invoke the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act (UAPA) in the Delhi riots case.

  • The Court questioned the intent behind protests and whether the mere establishment of protest sites warrants UAPA.
  • Accused individuals, including Umar Khalid and Sharjeel Imam, are seeking bail while the prosecution cites WhatsApp messages as evidence.
  • The Court demanded specific evidence indicating instigation of violence as opposed to mere organization of protests.
  • Observations were made regarding Delhi Police's selective naming of accused based on WhatsApp chats.
"Is it your case that only setting up of a protest site is good enough for UAPA or is it your case that protest site which resulted in a violence is good enough for a case under UAPA." - Justice Navin Chawla

The hearing continues as the Court examines the implications of the evidence presented by the prosecution.

item.title: Formula E Race Case: Telangana High Court Permits KT Rama Rao's Lawyer To Watch ACB Interrogation Through ... - Live Law - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Telangana High Court Allows KT Rama Rao's Lawyer to Observe ACB Interrogation in Formula E Case

Date: January 8, 2023 | Source: Live Law

The Telangana High Court has permitted BRS MLA KT Rama Rao's lawyer to observe the interrogation proceedings at the Anti Corruption Bureau (ACB) in the Formula E race case. This ruling allows the lawyer to be present in a library opposite the interrogation room with visibility.

  • The court clarified that the presence of a lawyer during interrogation is not a fundamental right.
  • Justice K Lakshman stated that the lawyer could observe the proceedings from a library room with a glass window.
  • The investigating officer was directed to ensure the visibility for the lawyer.
  • The court dismissed Rao's plea to quash the FIR regarding alleged irregularities during his tenure as Urban Development Minister.
  • Rao's counsel referred to a Supreme Court judgment allowing a lawyer's presence at a visible distance during interrogations.
“What is the problem in permitting? Petitioner and Investigating Officer will be in one room. Advocate will sit in the visitor's room. Only thing is you have to provide him with some visibility.” - Justice K Lakshman

In conclusion, the court's decision aims to balance the rights of the accused with the investigative process, allowing for some level of lawyer supervision during the interrogation.
